entry.title: Why does Armenia need its own stock exchange?

media:group.media:title: Why does Armenia need its own stock exchange?
media:group.media:description:
Konstantin Saroyan, Secretary General at the Yerevan-based Federation of Euro-Asian Stock Exchanges, joined CivilNet‚Äôs Mark Dovich to talk about the importance of Armenia‚Äôs sole stock exchange and explain why Armenia‚Äôs capital markets have been so slow to develop over the years. He also discussed the need to improve corporate governance in Armenia ‚Äì and how actually to do so.
0:00 What exactly does the Federation of Euro-Asian Stock Exchanges do? 4:48 Why have Armenia‚Äôs capital markets been so slow to develop? 10:48 What work needs to be done for Armenian companies to go public? 12:29 How can Armenian companies improve corporate governance?

media:group.media:title: Armenia has ‚Äòhighest expectations‚Äô for Washington talks with Azerbaijan, says lawmaker
media:group.media:description:
üìçU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken launched multi-day negotiations in Washington with Foreign Ministers Ararat Mirzoyan of Armenia and Jeyhun Bayramov of Azerbaijan. üìçVoice of America‚Äôs Armenian service reported that negotiations on a document titled ‚Äúagreement on the normalization of relations‚Äù are set to run through Thursday, citing unnamed senior State Department officials. üìçArmenia has the ‚Äúhighest possible expectations‚Äù for the Washington talks,, ruling party lawmaker Arman Yeghoyan told reporters.

entry.title: What happens if Aliyev‚Äôs maximalist demands are actually met?

media:group.media:title: What happens if Aliyev‚Äôs maximalist demands are actually met?
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet host and analyst Eric Hacopian discussed Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev‚Äôs maximalist demands for the Armenia-Azerbaijan peace process and what would happen if a new conflict in the region erupts that leaves Nagorno-Karabakh fully under Azerbaijani control. Eric also talked about Azerbaijani rule over Nagorno-Karabakh would mean for Armenian society and democracy, as well as its ramifications for the other major players in the region.

entry.title: ‚ÄúI seized the opportunity to grow and to give in Gyumri‚Äù, Sarah Stites

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúI seized the opportunity to grow and to give in Gyumri‚Äù, Sarah Stites
media:group.media:description:
Sarah Stites sat down with Lara Tcholakian to share her role and achievements as the Development Officer at the Emily Aregak Center and at the Caritas Aregak Foundation in Gyumri, Armenia‚Äôs second city. She explained how the center provides free therapy to kids with special needs and provides support to parents. In 2018, Sarah left her home in the Washington, D.C., area and moved to Gyumri to become better acquainted with her Armenian roots and to be of service to the community. The discussion revolved around topics of authenticity, self-fulfillment, self-realization, social media, human relations, wellness and health. Also being of Irish and Scottish descent, Sarah talked about the 25% Armenian heritage she inherited from her maternal grandfather, Charles Mooshian, who was from Kharpert, and the connections she feels with her Armenian roots. The interview concluded with a discussion of the challenges Sarah witnessed during the 2020 war in Artsakh and the lessons she learned from those difficult times.
About Sarah Stites Based in Gyumri since 2018, Sarah Stites is the Development Officer at the Caritas Aregak Foundation, an organization striving to improve the quality of life for people in Armenia with disabilities through therapy, training and pathways to employment. She is a traveling wordsmith and communications specialist exploring her Armenian roots. She is passionate about programs that build empathy and connections between people from different walks of life. She is also an avid runner, hiker and swimmer. In 2021, Sarah founded Gyumri Restored, a U.S.-registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit that supports, among other projects, small-scale home renovations for families with children with severe physical disabilities. or more information, please visit donorsee.com/gyumrirestored.
Program overview In a new, open setting, Lara deconstructs inherited cultural and historical narratives, memories, life lessons and experiences from change catalysts. Her guests reflect on the stories, people, events and mindsets that have shaped their professional and personal lives, enabling them to create a more mindful life.
#MindfulLeaders #InheritedLegacies #CivilNet
